top_comment.text:
Wow! It is 1 am here and I am watching your video before bed (half a sleep 
lol) I am so exited for your next Q&A video! :D Can you tell us what is 
your most favorite holiday and what special thing that makes this Holiday 
so special to you? For me, I love New Year, we don't have Christmas but we 
have a New Year. I have a lot of memories from past around new year, we 
used to decorate our house with lights and decorate out small Christmas 
tree, even it was small it was a lot of fun! We used to make a table, cook 
special food, and bake something special usually Nopoleon Cake. (I don't 
know if you have heard about this cake). Smell of oranges brings me back 
those memories.... :')﻿
top_comment.author: Shokhsanam Jones

comments.text:

of my mom and my sisters :)
comments.author: Shokhsanam Jones

comments.text:
+Shokhsanam Jones Hi Shokhsanam, great questions, i added them to my list 
and will answer them on Thursday. I just love Christmas too. It is my 
absolute favorite time. The smells like you said and the colors. And all 
the traditional food. I do know Nopoleon cake, it's lovely. In Ireland we 
have fig pudding and mince pies. A lot of fruit and alcohol in our 
desserts. :) I love food memories

captions.text: (Music)

Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking
Gingerbread Trifle

Hi Bold Bakers! I am so excited that the holiday
season is here because it's my favorite time

of year. This week I'm sharing with you a
BIG & BOLD twist on a holiday trifle using

my favorite Irish gingerbread recipe. Also,
today I am airing another episode of my Chocolicious

series over on the Kin Community Channel.
Make sure you stay around to check that out.
So let's get baking!

We're going to start out by making the gingerbread.
Now a few of you have very kindly asked me

to show you how to make more traditional Irish
recipes. And it doesn't get more traditional

than this. This is a recipe I've used for
over 10 years. It's my absolute favorite.

This little book is my go-to for Irish recipes
and it's by a lady called Biddy White Lennon.

I've had it for a very long time as you can
tell by the color of it and the dog ears and
the fact that there's cake batter in there.

So in a large bowl we're going to mix our
dry ingredients. Our flour, ground ginger,

which is a very important ingredient in Gingerbread.
Ground cinnamon for more great flavor and

warmth. And always, salt. Now simply whisk
these together until well combined.

Now for the rest of the recipe, we're going
to head over to the stove.

In a heavy bottom sauce pan, we're going to
add in our butter, molasses or treacle. And

dark brown sugar. Now you want to heat these
over a very low heat until the sugar dissolves.

You don't want to let it get too hot. We're
going to turn off the heat now, let it sit,

cool down a little bit before we add in the
rest of the ingredients.

Now that the molasses mix has cooled, we can
add in the eggs. Pour in your mixed eggs.

And then whisk together nice and fast so they
don't cook on the mix. Once the eggs are in,

we're going to whisk in the flour-spice mix.
Normally you wouldn't see me whisk in flour

to a batter but it's important for this recipe
because if you don't you could end up with

lumps because it's actually a really thin
batter.

Our last step for the gingerbread is adding
in the warm milk and baking soda. You add

in the baking soda, which is a raising agent,
into the milk. So we're going to pour this

quickly into the other mix. I'm not one for
unnecessary steps, and I know heating up the

milk and adding the baking soda seems unnecessary,
but I've done it for 10 years. It's worked.

Biddy told me to do it so I did it. This is
what your gingerbread should look like. It's

not super thick. It's kind of runny. And it
makes beautiful gingerbread. So let's get
it into the tins and into the oven.

Now simply pour your gingerbread into two
loaf tins that are lined with parchment paper.

So do you see all of these bubbles? This is
the baking soda activated. That's why you

want to move kind of fast and get them into
the oven because you want to capture those
bubbles while it's in the oven baking.

We're going to bake the gingerbread at 300
degrees for 45 minutes. Once that time is

up, take them out, cover them with tin foil,
and put them back in for another 15 and they're

going to kind of steam and create a beautiful
sticky layer that you get on the top.

For more great holiday recipes, you'll want
to check out my Triple Chocolate Pumpkin Brownie

over on the Kin Community Channel. And also,
don't forget to subscribe to my channel.

The next layer in our trifle is a cream cheese
and orange filling. And it goes really well

with the gingerbread and with the cranberries
that we're going to do next.

In a stand mixer or a hand mixer, whisk your
cream cheese until nice and soft. It's always

best using room temperature cream cheese.
It makes it much easier. To your cream cheese,

add in your sugar. Orange zest. The juice
of the same orange. And lastly, add your cream.

Then turn your machine on medium speed and
continue whisking. As you can see, it's much

thicker now because the whipped cream has
whipped in there and you have a beautiful

thick consistency. Now make sure you taste
it. Mmm, so good!

The third layer in our trifle is going to
be a cranberry sauce. Now there's nothing

that says holidays like cranberries. In a
heavy bottom sauce pan over low heat, we're

going to add in our cranberries. Water. Sugar
because as beautiful as cranberries are they

do tend to be a little on the tart side. Some
lovely orange zest to add that nice citrus

flavor to the cranberries. And for extra punch,
we're going to add in fresh orange juice.

You want to cook your cranberry sauce for
around 8-10 minutes until the sugar has dissolved,

all the cranberries start to pop, and you
see the beautiful color coming out in them.

So we're going to set this aside, let it go
cold, and then we can start assembling our
trifle.

So a lot of you have asked for a Question
and Answer video so next Thursday you're going

to get one. But let me know what questions
you have in the comments below like where

am I from in Ireland. Where did I go to school?
What is my favorite candy bar? Am I dog or

a cat person? Like anything you like and I'll
try to get to as many of them as I can.

When your gingerbread is ready, we're going
to cube it and get it ready for our trifle.

When you're storing it, keep it in parchment
paper. It just keeps it nice and moist. This

layer on top is exactly what you want from
a gingerbread. It's sticky. It's moist. It's

kind of molassessy. So to use this for the
trifle, I'm going to cut it into little cubes.

Now my favorite part of all the dessert, apart
from the eating, is the assembly.

In the bottom of my trifle dish, I'm going
to do a nice generous layer of gingerbread.

Ok let's speed things up because we have a
lot of layers to do. For the next layer, I'm

going to go in with my beautiful cream cheesy
orange filling. Do not be shy with this, it's

one of the best parts I think! And spread
it all the way around to the sides and get

it in all the nooks and crannies. Top off
that with your cranberry sauce layer. Spread

it evenly all the way around. Look at this
beautiful color with the cream cheese, the

gingerbread. Of course, this is a BIG & BOLD
trifle so we're going again with all the layers.

Another layer of your orange cream cheese
filling. Then top if off with some cranberry

sauce. A few pieces of gingerbread. And some
fresh orange zest. And there you have it,
a BIG & BOLD trifle for any holiday occasion.

If you don't want to make a big giant trifle,
you can always make individual ones in ice

cream bowls or even in mason jars. This is
soo good. You guys are going to love this!

I really hope you enjoyed my gingerbread trifle.
Don't forget to check out my triple chocolate

pumpkin brownie over on the Kin Community
Channel. Don't forget to subscribe and I'll

see you back here again next Thursday for

title: Holiday Gingerbread Trifle (Irish Recipe) - Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking Ep. 41
